awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   P2C2--Reconstructing Deglacial and Holocene Climate Variability in Southeast Asia Using Speleothems and Isotope-Enabled Model Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
The Asian Monsoon system is an important component of the global climate system that plays a major role in the transport of heat and moisture from the tropics to higher latitudes.  Even small variations in the strength and/or timing of seasonal rainfall can have significant impacts on the billions of people living within the Asian monsoon domain, yet climate model projections of future monsoon changes still remain uncertain.  While paleoclimate records have significantly advanced our understanding of summer monsoon variability in some regions, we still know very little about the range and mechanisms of monsoon variability in Southeast Asia. 

This research, a collaborative effort between scientists from the University of California, Irvine and William Patterson College of New Jersey, will generate high-resolution speleothem (cave calcite deposit) records of past hydroclimate variability over the last 20,000 years from Laos, a key site at the interface between the Indian and East Asian monsoon systems.  The new oxygen isotope records will document changes in Southeast Asian monsoon strength on sub-decadal to orbital timescales, filling in a key spatial and temporal gap in the paleoclimate record of the tropics. Through integrating paleoclimate proxy data, instrumental climate data, and climate model analyses, the project will address three main questions:  (1) How has Southeast Asian monsoon intensity varied over the past 20,000 years in response to orbital forcing, millennial-scale abrupt climate events, and interannual to multi-decadal climate modes?; (2) What are the mechanisms that control precipitation and speleothem oxygen isotopes on interannual to orbital timescales in Laos?; and (3) How do the Laos speleothem records relate to broader spatial and temporal patterns of past climate variability in the tropical Indo-Pacific, the Asian monsoon region, and high latitudes?  In addition to the scientific outcomes, this project will provide research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students and will be incorporated in outreach efforts aimed at improving the participation of underrepresented groups in the geosciences.   For instance, a hands-on field and laboratory exercise on paleoclimate, climate change, and native culture will be developed for the NSF funded American Indian Summer Institute in Earth System Science held at the University of California, Irvine each summer.

por.por_cntn:
Despite significant advances in our understanding of tropical Indo-Pacific and monsoon climate variability on orbital (~10-100,000 year) to millennial (1000 year) timescales, we still know very little about the range and mechanisms of variability in the Southeast Asian monsoon (SEAM) region. To address this need, we have developed new high-resolution speleothem stable isotope [i.e. oxygen (δ18O) and carbon (δ13C)] records from Tham Doun Mai (TM) Cave, Laos. The primary objectives of this research were to determine:  (1) How the SEAM intensity has varied over the past ~35,000 years in response to orbital forcing, millennial scale abrupt climate events, and interannual to multi-decadal climate modes; (2) The primary controls on precipitation and speleothem δ18O on interannual to orbital timescales in Laos through analysis of isotope-enabled general circulation model (GCM) simulations (IsoGSM and GISS ModelE) and forward-modeling of speleothem δ18O; and (3) How the Laos speleothem records relate to broader spatial and temporal patterns of past climate variability in the tropical Indo-Pacific, the Asian monsoon region, and high-latitudes.

 

Results from our analysis of the IsoGSM model simulated precipitation δ18O and instrument climate data (Yang et al., 2016) have advanced our understanding of the controls on isotopic variability in SEAM precipitation and paleoclimate archives.  A primary outcome from this work is that variations in monsoon intensity and upstream rainout, which have been recently invoked to explain coherent speleothem δ18O variability on orbital and millennial timescales, also operate over shorter, interannual timescales.  Therefore, proxy records from across the monsoon region that exhibit coherent interannual variations, likely reflect large scale interannual variability in monsoon intensity. However, our results also highlight a potential mechanism to explain incoherent variations across this region, through ENSO, which we show primarily exerts strong influence in northern India and Southeast Asia, including at the TM cave location.

 

We have also developed the first decadally-resolved speleothem δ18O and δ13C record in Laos, from two overlapping stalagmites from TM cave.  The records span the period from 37.7 kyr BP to the present and the age models are constrained by 35 U-Th dates. The orbital and millennial scale δ18O variability is remarkably similar to other Asian speleothem records (e.g. such as those from China), with the δ18O showing a precessional signal and clear δ18O increases (i.e. weaker monsoon) during various North Atlantic cold events (i.e. Heinrich Stadial events and the Younger Dryas). The strong similarity of speleothem δ18O records across the broad Asian monsoon region, in locations with quite different rainfall climatology, suggests that variations in upstream rainout and Indian monsoon strength are the dominant mechanism explaining orbital and millennial scale precipitation δ18O variability. In contrast to δ18O, TM speleothem δ13C is more likely reflective of local hydroclimate.  The δ13C record shows large positive excursions during these North Atlantic cold events, suggesting dry conditions. It is interesting to note, however, that the TM δ13C values diverge from δ18O during the early Holocene (~8-10,000 years ago) insolation maxima, suggesting that dry conditions in SE Asia were synchronous with increased Asian Monsoon intensity during this time; this interpretation is further supported by speleothem greyscale measurements, which reflect internal porosity mainly related to infiltration. Climate model analyses conducted with the isotope-enabled GISS Model E suggest dry conditions in SE Asia during insolation maxima may arise from decreased low-level moisture convergence over the Indo-China Peninsula as precipitation over India and East Asia increases, effectively drawing away moisture from our study site. 

 

Finally, results from our work provide the first evidence for a centennial-scale drying event during the late Holocene, coincident with the so-called ‘4.2 ka event’, which was characterized by extreme drought conditions in eastern Africa and Eurasia. The nature and geographical extent of this climate event has been a topic of great interest because of its potential connections with societal upheavals in western Asia and northeastern Africa. However, while paleoclimate data from India and southern China show evidence for a large-scale ‘megadrought’ during this period, there have hitherto been no high-resolution and well-dated records from mainland southeast Asia (MSEA) to document the regional footprint of this event. This is somewhat surprising because, whilst Archaeological research in mainland Southeast Asia is still a relatively recent endeavor, a gap in evidence called the “missing millennia” has emerged. The gap falls during the middle Holocene ca. 6000-4000 years BP when few sites have dated deposits. A suite of three Holocene δ18O and δ13C speleothem records from TM cave document one of, if not the, largest droughts of the Holocene between ~5 ka and ~3.5 ka, consistent in timing with the “missing millennia”; this suggests that this event may have had a significant impact on the human populations of the region at this time.
